Hi, this solution was discussed years ago, I can't remember where. 

**We don't do this now**, because the data would not be refreshed to 2nd level aggregation, then last dozens packages of metrics would NOT show up anymore until there is new data coming, which could be very confusing, especially when you do baseline testing or local testing.
Think you this way, you are doing a local test, and send 10+ segment to OAP, then nothing happens.

If you want to hold data for longer, you have to use some timer mechanism to refresh the cache if there is no incoming data recently. This would not be an easy coding model, and you have to add some kinds of lock, like Persistent Timer doing.

> you

Yes I see, I have not thought about that，still I think it would be a great improvement about performance , I will try to make it work about what you had mentioned.

> i cant see any info about use log

Please read trough the docs first, docs are definitely there for open source projects

https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/setup/service-agent/java-agent/Application-toolkit-log4j-1.x.md#grpc-reporter
https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/setup/service-agent/java-agent/Application-toolkit-log4j-2.x.md
https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/setup/service-agent/java-agent/Application-toolkit-logback-1.x.md
ElasticSearch 7 is supported, but JDK 6 is not. We are clear in the document.

This is a simple cause, you configure an appender but didn't use it, try 

```xml
<root level="INFO">
    <appender-ref ref="STDOUT"/>
    <appender-ref ref="grpc-log"/>
</root>
```

> > > Can we try to use server notify (if supported by the configuration center) to dynamically update the configuration?

> > My question would be, how do those client libs make push mode? In many known implementation, they are still using an internal ping to fake the push.

> 
> For Apollo, it's using long-polling mechanism.


If the configuration center naturally supports long connections, we can use this feature directly, the code will be simple. In addition, take apollo as an example. Its long polling is not an ordinary long polling, but a long connection. The client will be hanged after requesting the server. It can perform real-time synchronization configuration within a certain period of time, which is more efficient than timing tasks, and real-time synchronization configuration is also faster.

It has a chance to sync the data quicker, then read in a loop. Yes. 
But from the connection perspective, today's implementation also doesn't re-create connection every time.

Back to your question, if you want, this is possible. You could override `ConfigWatcherRegister#start` to make the timer disable easily. If you want to do this in Apollo, I would like to recommend you supporting both way(current and your proposal), because users are mostly using this way, and no one was asking for this.
